thread.title_full: Australia forced to select Test squad for New Zealand series off two days of Sheffield Shield play | The Advertiser

author: JAMIE PANDARAM
title: Australia forced to select squad for New Zealand series off two days of Sheffield Shield play
text:
AUSTRALIAN selector Mark Waugh has conceded that picking a Test squad to play New Zealand off just two days of Sheffield Shield cricket is hardly ideal, and wants the nation’s best to make a statement in the Matador Cup one-day tournament.
But with an international-stacked NSW side humiliating an inexperienced Cricket Australia XI by a record margin at Bankstown Oval on Monday, questions remain about the national team’s preparations for a Test series against the resurgent Kiwis.
CAPTAIN’S KNOCK: Steve Smith hammers massive ton for NSW
IN FORM: Marsh and Bancroft break 24-year record
After the postponement of the Bangladesh tour due to security concerns, Australia is left with a month of domestic 50-over cricket, and two days of Shield cricket before selectors must choose their squad for New Zealand, with the first Test starting November 5 in Brisbane.
Waugh says while one-day cricket is not desired for Test preparation, Australia has no choice now the Bangladesh tour is off.
Mitchell Starc was in the wickets against a weak CAXI side. Source: News Corp Australia
“It’s a different format, but you’ve seen players picked from one-day cricket for Test squads before so it does carry over,” Waugh said.
“It’s a different game obviously, you’ve got to bat for long periods in Test cricket, one-day cricket the most you can bat is 50 overs, but I think just the form, you can see if guys are batting and bowling well.
“If you’re not doing well it can count against you more so. You want to see all your players performing well.
“There’s only one Shield match before the first Test, we get two days to look at the first Shield round and then we pick the squad for the first and second Tests.
“You don’t have a lot of red-ball cricket, but there’s still a lot of cricket to be played, whether that’s better than going to Bangladesh in foreign conditions, whether that’s a better warm-up is questionable.
“But players are playing a lot of cricket these days, they’re used to swapping and changing formats, so whilst it’s probably not ideal we didn’t play the two Tests in Bangladesh it gives as a chance for some players to freshen up.”
David Warner and others will return to the Australia squad to face the Kiwis. Source: Getty Images
Test skipper Steve Smith followed the script with a commanding 143 not out as NSW rolled the Cricket Australia XI in the opening Matador Cup match at Bankstown Oval.
Blues opener Nic Maddinson also notched a ton (108), and said he relishes an international recall having played two Twenty20s for Australia in 2013 and 2014.
“I don’t think I’d play cricket if I didn’t want to play at the highest level possible,” Maddinson said.
“But it’s about improving and staying hungry for runs in the next couple of weeks.”
West Australian openers Cameron Bancroft (176) and Shaun Marsh (109) — who were both picked in Australia’s squad to Bangladesh — also ensured they remain firmly in the national selectors’ minds with centuries against South Australia.
NSW won by a record margin for a domestic one-dayer of 279 runs, scoring 3-338 and then skittling the CAXI for just 59 runs, with Mitchell Starc bagging 6-25.
Waugh all but confirmed that NSW spinner Stephen O’Keefe, who would have formed a double-spin combination with Nathan Lyon in turning Bangladesh conditions, would miss out on the New Zealand series given the faster pitches in Australia.
Steve Smith blasted his way to a massive ton in NSW colours. Source: News Corp Australia
“The squad from Bangladesh, it’s going to look different for New Zealand, there is no doubt about it because you didn’t have [David] Warner, [Josh] Hazlewood and [Mitchell] Johnson, so there’s three players straight away you’d imagine would come back into the reckoning for the first Test.
“And different conditions, you’re not going to have two spinners at The Gabba in the first Test.
“There’s going to be some guys picked for that tour who are probably going to get shuffled back down the order a little bit, but you can’t do anything about it.
“At least their names are there, they got picked for an Australian tour, they can take comfort from the fact they’re definitely in the reckoning, but the reality is it will be a different 12 for the first Test in Brisbane to what would have been picked in Bangladesh.”
